content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Overall, I think this is a good clash. While it may be hard to determine the goal in reverse, it is doable within the time limit. If you want to make it easier, perhaps adding a test case like 332211 => 994411 would help reveal the pattern.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: This seems like it would be incredibly hard to do in reverse. If there was a way to make it not be available in reverse, then it seems like a very doable problem

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: It seems nearly impossible to do in reverse
This seems extremely difficult to do in reverse

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's actually quite doable in reverse mode

"by raising each digit of n to the power of l" => at the first sight, we can think "to the power of l"
After reading the example, I understood it is "by raising each digit of n to the power of the length of l"
Meawhile,  nice one ! Upvoted it !

Your contribution has been uploaded twice. Please remove one of them. The other link is:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/59415d68c6bcec29739305d7fc075f75f047e

Goal section
* Please fix the typo: "rising" => "raising".

* I would suggest to change "125%10 = 5" to "125 => 5" and "216%10" to "216 => 6" to avoid giving away a hint in the operator to use in the code.

* I would suggest to delete "(holds for any single digit number)" to avoid excessive explanation.

Input section
* Please change "An integer" to "An integer [[n]]".

* Please move " 0 <= n < 10^123435" to Constraints section. Please also revise the upper limit because
(a) it does not reflect the actual cases being tested,
(b) you need to declare n as a long (or a string because even a long may not be good enough and there will be overflow...) instead of an int in the stub generator if a very very large number is really included in the test cases.

Cases
* Please change the cases so that there are no duplicates with the same inputs.

Game modes
* Is it easy to guess the requirements in Reverse mode?

Thanks.

Thanks for your comment.

This was the first simple idea that came as my first contribution. I am surprised about the number of directions it can be pushed.

In the current formulation with last digit (plus length being positive), replacements are cyclic, so the task can be solved with simple character replacement. I thought I can make this observation necessary with big [[n]], but it doesn't seem to work, and probably it makes no sense in CoC. I removed the constraint.

I think it is fine for Revers. I will just fiddle a bit with examples to lead the reader.

Corrected. Thank you!
I have doubts it reads cleaner. Maybe someone else can read, as I am already biased.
Thanks for your comment. Can you think about any possible hint making it easier, or is it just too hard?
Do you think adding some more cases could solve it? I know I am balancing here and if it is not possible, I am willing to remove reverse.
Thanks for your comment. I have added your suggestion.
